messages: a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (15:00): oh nice
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (15:00): http://labs.qt.nokia.com/2011/02/24/qt-people-our-javascript-platform-is-burning-rubber/
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (15:11): edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e: b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea hostsit
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (15:11): 7f9405da4034bf43083e64b57302a8e6: But there's nothing of interest of it, and it makes me seem a horrible self-centered asshole
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (15:11): a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554, i know
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (15:11): edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e: so ask him ?:P
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (15:11): a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554, maybe I should set up a bribing strategy as I'm going to visit the Swedes soon
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (15:12): b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea is a busy man
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (15:26): ms2ger: nice idea :)
7f9405da4034bf43083e64b57302a8e6 (15:26): a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554, killing off URL that held content s is a bad deed in itself. meditate on that.
7f9405da4034bf43083e64b57302a8e6 (15:28): a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554, maybe you should write only stuff you would like to read?
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (15:28): a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554: It's too late to change how you seem to people, once you've already published stuff
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (15:29): ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c: I know
7f9405da4034bf43083e64b57302a8e6 (15:29): a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554, keep the blog, and get better. it is great to look at past stuff and see that you are better now.

ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (15:29): Everything will hang around forever in caches and quotes and archives, so you'll never be able to hide it, and you'll just have the added negative impression that you're no good at archiving your own material

a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (15:30): Meh, it seems to me no worse than physically detroying stuff. No, you can never be sure you've destroyed everything, but, it can still seem worthwhile to try‚Ä¶
7f9405da4034bf43083e64b57302a8e6 (15:30): you will annoy people
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (15:31): Better to keep it where you can control it and add a disclaimer to give readers the appropriate context
7f9405da4034bf43083e64b57302a8e6 (15:31): dead links, man. dead links.
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (15:31): hates ever physically destroying anything, too :-p
7f9405da4034bf43083e64b57302a8e6 (15:31): what ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c said. there are blogs i read who have a warning on articles older than 6 months.
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (15:31): uses URLs for that
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (15:31): (though I wouldn't if I started over)
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (15:32): (dates in URLs are almost always terrible)
cc097e0d7183ae8436e7df709553c8c0 (15:43): what's wrong with dates in urls for a blog?
7f9405da4034bf43083e64b57302a8e6 (15:56): cc097e0d7183ae8436e7df709553c8c0, dates in urls are ugly.
7f9405da4034bf43083e64b57302a8e6 (15:56): <http://example.org/the-title> is almost universally better remembered than <http://example.org/1234-56-78/the-title>
7f9405da4034bf43083e64b57302a8e6 (15:57): where i do not object is if the dates are the title, as with chat logs or {daily|weekly} articles.
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (15:58): cc097e0d7183ae8436e7df709553c8c0, doesn't seem good to hide metadata in URLs
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (15:58): cc097e0d7183ae8436e7df709553c8c0, and they make them more lengthy too
7f9405da4034bf43083e64b57302a8e6 (15:59): edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e, the great rewriting purge can permanently change the ugly face of your blog. but you know that :)
7f9405da4034bf43083e64b57302a8e6 (15:59): i use only the title
7f9405da4034bf43083e64b57302a8e6 (15:59): wordpress defaults are a mess
7f9405da4034bf43083e64b57302a8e6 (15:59): but it is pretty good at redirecting from wrongly input URLs to the correct one
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (16:00): my blog has been rewritten too many times already :)
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (16:00): now I only try to simplify every now and then
da5121879fff54b08b69ec54d9ac2bf6 (16:00): They provide a useful hierarchy when example.com/2011/, example.com/2011/02/ and example.com/2011/02/foobar/ are all available.
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (16:00): da5121879fff54b08b69ec54d9ac2bf6, but dated hierarchies suck...
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (16:01): (my blog works that way though)
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (16:01): besides /2011/ and /2011/02/ and /2011/02/html-development I even support /2011/02/24/
da5121879fff54b08b69ec54d9ac2bf6 (16:02): disagrees about the colour of this particular bikeshed. :P
f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220 (16:02): da5121879fff54b08b69ec54d9ac2bf6, it's possible to implement the dated archives without having to have the URLs of the articles themselves include the dates.
7f9405da4034bf43083e64b57302a8e6 (16:10): what lachy says :)
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (16:12): Obviously TabAtkins is right and urls should be absurdly long hash strings
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (16:13): Then people won't get the silly idea that they can remember or manipulate them
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (16:13): If I were evil I might wonder if working for a search company gives you a conflict of interest here ;)
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (16:13): b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea, kind of like git's approach to revision identifiers?  :)
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (16:14): 88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762: Are you suggesting that git should use the commit message as the revision identifier?
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (16:14): No, but I like your twisted and evil way of thinking.
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (16:14): That wouldn't work, though, because multiple commits might have the same message.
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (16:14): Same with blog post titles

88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (16:15): Has anyone else noticed that whenever something goes wrong in Windows, it tells you "application X/website X is causing a problem", but whenever it's pretending to do something helpful, it always says "Windows has fixed this problem"?
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (16:15): Like: https://bugzilla.wikimedia.org/show_bug.cgi?id=27677#c18
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (16:15): "the website continues to have a problem", "When a website causes a failure or crash"
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (16:15): As though websites are able to crash non-buggy web browsers.
cc097e0d7183ae8436e7df709553c8c0 (16:16): yeah, i was a bit surprised to read the ie crash message first time i saw it
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (16:17): It's really the same as how IEBlog posts always try to spin things to dishonestly paint themselves as being better than their competitors.
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (16:17): Microsoft is just evil that way, I guess.

88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (16:19): (note: in contrast to spinning things to honestly or at least semi-honestly paint themselves as being better than their competitors, which is okay, e.g., touting their GPU acceleration or something)
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (16:19): (as opposed to claiming that they address all bugs they receive and their competitors somehow don't)
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (16:19): (or that they're more standards-compliant because they pass almost 100% of their own test suite)
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (16:19): (both of those are just lies)
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (16:22): Wow, I just managed to completely crash Chrome.
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (16:22): That's the first time I can remember that happening.
cc097e0d7183ae8436e7df709553c8c0 (16:23): 88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762: no, there was a problem with the web site you were visiting
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (16:24): Yes, it must be running some malicious code that only happens to be targeted at IE on Windows XP.
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (16:24): fwiw, http://dvcs.w3.org/hg/from-origin/raw-file/tip/Overview.html bit raw still, I need some sleep
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (16:24): It was probably written by some frustrated web developers who wanted to take out their anger on IE users.
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (16:24): (there's no processing model there)
cc097e0d7183ae8436e7df709553c8c0 (16:24): i thought you said chrome crashed
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (16:24): 88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762: It wasn't a google site then?
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (16:24): Oh, you were talking about that.
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (16:24): Well, actually, it was Chrome preferences.
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (16:24): So Chrome kind of has to take the blame either way.
cc097e0d7183ae8436e7df709553c8c0 (16:25): i wonder who IE would blame in that situation
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (16:25): 88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762: You're not supposed to change preferences if you use Chrome
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (16:25): Didn't you know?

88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (16:25): edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e, I realize people have bikeshedded over the name a bunch already, but: "From-Origin"?  What relevance does that have to the functionality?  How about "Restrict-Embedding" or "Limit-Embed" or something?
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (16:26): If only you recognsied the One True Way, you wouldn't have this sort of problem
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (16:26): I hope you have learnt your lesson
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (16:26): cc097e0d7183ae8436e7df709553c8c0, 'The website "about:preferences" caused a problem'

88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (16:26): b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea, I was actually editing my form autofill info.  I guess I'm just supposed to have the same name, address, and phone number as every other Chrome user?
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (16:27): You're probably supposed to put all that information in your google account
cc097e0d7183ae8436e7df709553c8c0 (16:27): that'd be the case if all other chrome users switched to another browser
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (16:27): 88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762, Embed-Only-From-Origin was the only somewhat appropriate alternative but not liked so far
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (16:27): 88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762, I hope this can become part of CSP (or CP)
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (16:28): until something drastic like that happens I'm not gonna bother renaming anything
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (16:28): that'll just cause confusion
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (16:29): I love how Linux updates just modify everything in place instead of requiring a reboot.  It makes things so exciting.
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (16:29): Large parts of the text on my screen just turned into little boxes.
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (16:29): waits to see if they turn back
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (16:31): wonders that a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 hasn't started singing yet
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (16:32): Nope, they didn't turn back.
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (16:32): Looks like my Ubuntu Bold font disappeared.
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (16:33): This is why I hate other OSes, they're so boring.
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (16:33): makes his window titles italic instead of bold for now
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (16:33): I'm only half-joking.
8925426ae91d6282f262eb2ee108bdc0 (16:33): Looks like I had better luck with my update than you did haha
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (16:34): Most of what I learned about OSes and hardware, I learned from having to fix Linux when it broke.
8925426ae91d6282f262eb2ee108bdc0 (16:34): That's the best way, if you ask me
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (16:35): Now Chrome has lost my open tabs.  This is the first time it's seriously annoyed me in . . . a long time.
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (16:36): Oh well, nothing important.

ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (16:38): Other OSes are annoying since they don't happily let you install a critical security update to your kernel and then not reboot and still remain unknowingly vulnerable
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (16:38): Actually, Ubuntu does tell you to reboot on kernel updates.
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (16:38): But not on, e.g., libc or X updates, even for security vulnerabilities.
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (16:39): So unless you restart all updated programs, you still might be vulnerable.
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (16:39): Ubuntu doesn't count as proper Linux, it's all user-friendly and stuff
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (16:39): Of course, it's not like anyone exploits non-Windows desktops much.
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (16:39): And for servers, remote execution is the only real worry in most cases, and that's pretty rare.
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (16:40): hasn't rebooted his server in 75 days, although that's mostly because he has no working fallback

ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (16:40): vaguely remembers getting reboot warnings when logging in on one of his Ubuntu servers, but not the other, and on the first one he didn't bother rebooting anyway

ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (16:41): Local exploits still seem dangerous on servers, because servers run rubbish PHP scripts that are full of bugs and let attackers upload and execute arbitrary code
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (16:42): (Fortunately attackers seem to usually just use it for adding spam onto all your pages)
